Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Subatomic Physics at Virginia Union University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM faculty at HBCUs to pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Virginia Union University (VUU), a private, liberal-arts HBCU, will conduct research aimed at understanding the neutron structure function. This project will support the newly-established physics programs by expanding research opportunities available to students and enhancing the department's research infrastructure. The education and research experiences will contribute to VUU's efforts to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in physics and also help prepare students for graduate school and the Nation's STEM workforce.

The goal of the proposed study is to establish a collaborative experimental subatomic physics program that contributes to the fundamental understanding of the neutron. The PI will undertake slow controls work for a high-impact and highly anticipated measurement of the fundamental structure of the neutron. In addition, the PI will compare published structure function data from charged lepton and neutrino scattering on heavier targets to better model how nuclei may be observed differently from electromagnetic charged lepton and electroweak probes. Specifically, the PI will contribute to slow controls software development necessary for monitoring and archiving data associated with the gas deuteron gas target for the planned Barely Offshell Nucleon Structure (BONuS12) experiment. The PI will also conduct work to refine the structure function for Lead-82. Overall this program will create a VUU research presence in the international subatomic physics community as well as elevate the status of this HBCU and attract more students in physics. This project will be conducted in collaboration with the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (Jefferson Lab).

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award 1700333 "RIA: Subatomic Physics at VUU" has helped PI Dr. N. Kalantarians establish an active research program in experimental nuclear physics at Virginia Union University. The PI leveraged his connection with Jefferson Lab (in Newport News) to begin work on slow controls software to controller/sensor development for an experiment on measuring the fundamental structure and dynamics of the neutron, and analysis of nuclear cross-sections. The underlying theme of this program however, has been to find the undergraduate talent in Physics/Engineering/STEM at VUU and the surrounding Richmond area. 

These 2 parts of this RIA have served as vehicles for training VUU Physics/Engineering/STEM majors in data analytics, instrumentation, and software - hence, obtaining highly valuable experience for their career paths. Through the lifetime of this award, 6 students have participated in research under the PI's mentorship. From these participants, one was accepted in to a competitive Conference Experiences for Undergraduates and one became coauthor on a paper.      

The slow controls work entailed reading out the vital quantities (pressure ans temperature) of the gas-system of the central detector for experiment E12-06-113. This had students involved in helping test/build/write electronics, mechanical systems, and software. Analysis of data obtained from the slow controls then began. Most of the student participants were involved in this effort. They went on to present their work at various conferences, including at American Physical Society (APS).

The nuclear cross-section analysis involved obtaining published data on the F2 structure function, which involves the cross-section in more accurately characterizing the quark content of nuclei, and comparing them to F2 for the proton and neutron. This served as a novel method in studying the dynamic and structural modifications for various nuclei. The student participant played a vital role in helping format these data in to readable form for the analysis as well as helping visualize the initial data. These were significant contributions and earned him coauthorship in the publication Phys. Rev. C 103 015201 (2021). This experience in good part helped this student participant find a job as a programmer at IBM, upon graduating.    

The Coronavirus pandemic emerged during the final year of this award, prompting everyone involved to go online. With discussions and encouragement from the PD, the PI got creative with how to successfully finish this award. Hence, from this the VUU Physics department was able to support student officers of the Physics club who helped found the National Society of Black Physicists VUU chapter. The PI was also enabled to purchase a 3D printer for VUU Physics as well as for (collaborative) use by various other programs, including Fine Arts.   

This award has enriched VUU Physics and the PI's career in numerous ways. It has helped impact the starting careers for several VUU students - especially in getting them to realize that they do indeed belong in Physics/Engineering/STEM. The capabilities afforded by this RIA were paramount in his successfully obtaining an EiR (Award 2000108) in 2020, that will build further upon this program.
